metadata.case_name: Navnit Lal C. Javeri v. Income Tax Authorities

facts.text: Appellant holds 11 out of 845 shares in Malegaon Electricity Co. Private Ltd., value Rs. 100 each, business of supplying electricity to Malegaon residents.
In 1955, appellant took a loan amounting to over Rs. 4 lakhs from the company.
8th Income-Tax Officer issued notice under s. 22 of the Act to appellant for assessment year 1956-57.

Income-Tax Officer computed appellant's income at Rs. 3,58,460, including Rs. 2,83,126 as accumulated profits of the company deemed dividend under s. 2(6A)(e) and included as income from other sources under s. 12(1B).
Appellant appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner, which dismissed the appeal.
Appellant filed second appeal before Income Tax Appellate Tribunal, pending when writ filed.
Appellant filed writ petition in Bombay High Court under Articles 226 and 227 challenging validity of s. 12(1B) read with s. 2(6A)(e) as ultra vires.
Bombay High Court rejected challenge vide judgment dated July 30, 1962 in Special Civil Application No. 69 of 1962, granted certificate.
Sections 2(6A)(e) and 12(1B) introduced by Finance Act 15 of 1955, effective April 1, 1955.
Minister for Revenue gave assurance in Parliament that outstanding loans refunded genuinely before June 30, 1955, would not be taxed.
Central Board of Revenue issued Circular No. 20 dated May 10, 1955, binding under s. 58, exempting genuinely refunded loans before June 30, 1955.
Appellant's proportionate share in accumulated profits Rs. 2,83,126 is 11/845 i.e., Rs. 3,686; balance Rs. 2,79,440 attributed to other shareholders.

legal_issues.text: Whether s. 12(1B) read with s. 2(6A)(e) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 is constitutionally valid, within legislative competence under Entry 82 List I Seventh Schedule, and does not violate Art. 19(1)(f) and (g).
Whether loan to shareholder can be deemed dividend/income rationally connected to concept of income.
Whether provision imposes unreasonable restrictions under Art. 19(1)(f).

petitioner_arguments.text: Impugned provision beyond legislative competence under Entry 82 List I as loan cannot be treated as income.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Entry 82 List I Seventh Schedule; Navinchandra Mafatlal v. CIT

petitioner_arguments.text: Offends Art. 19(1)(f)(g), not saved by cl. 5 or 6; should require ITO to consider if loan genuine or device.
Deems entire loan as dividend exceeding proportionate share (Rs. 2,79,440 not appellant's income).

respondent_arguments.text: Word 'income' in Entry 82 to be construed liberally; loans by closely held companies are devices to evade tax on accumulated profits.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Navinchandra Mafatlal v. CIT; Sardar Baldev Singh v. CIT; Balaji v. ITO; s. 23A

respondent_arguments.text: Fiction rationally connected to prevent evasion; applies only to non-money-lending companies, post-notice loans.
Does not violate Art. 19(1)(f)(g) or Art. 14.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: K. M. S. Lakshmana Aiyar v. Addl. ITO

court_reasoning.text: Income in Entry 82 liberally construed; includes capital gains; loans by controlled private companies are tax evasion devices to avoid s. 23A.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rational connection between deemed dividend and income concept; legislature can create fiction for mischief.

court_reasoning.text: Conditions limit application: non-public company, shareholder borrower, to extent of accumulated profits, not ordinary money-lending, outstanding.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Past loans exempted if genuinely refunded by June 30, 1955 per circular.

court_reasoning.text: Does not violate Art. 19(1)(f)(g); no fundamental right to borrow tax-free from own company; reasonable restriction.
Dissent (Raghubar Dayal J.): Loan not income per natural meaning (Eisner v. Macomber); exceeds proportionate share irrational; unreasonable under Art. 19(1)(f); distinguishes precedents.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No inquiry into genuineness; taxes excess over share.

holdings.text: s. 12(1B) read with s. 2(6A)(e) within legislative competence under Entry 82; does not violate Art. 19(1)(f)(g).

precedents_cited.case_name: Navinchandra Mafatlal v. CIT Bombay City
precedents_cited.relevance: Liberal construction of 'income' includes capital gains.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sardar Baldev Singh v. CIT Delhi Ajmer
precedents_cited.relevance: s. 23A valid to tax deemed distributed profits of company to shareholders to prevent evasion.

precedents_cited.case_name: Balaji v. ITO Special Investigation Circle
precedents_cited.relevance: s. 16(3)(a)(i)(ii) valid to include family income to prevent evasion.

precedents_cited.case_name: In re Central Provinces and Berar Sales of Motor Spirit Act 1938
K. M. S. Lakshmana Aiyar v. Addl. ITO
precedents_cited.relevance: Impugned section does not violate Art. 14.
Definition of income as gain from capital, labour or both.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Deems loans/advances by closely held companies as dividends to extent of accumulated profits; applied to assess appellant.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Legislative competence for income tax; fundamental rights challenge repelled.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; Bombay High Court judgment upheld; ss. 2(6A)(e) and 12(1B) held constitutionally valid (majority); Raghubar Dayal J. dissented holding them void.

key_quotes.text: "the word income used in the said entry must be given its ordinary, natural and grammatical meaning and that was, income is a thing that comes in."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "If the legislature realises that the private controlled companies generally adopt the device of making advances or giving loans to their shareholders with the object of evading the payment of tax, it can step in to meet this mischief."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Income may be defined as the gain derived from capital, from labour, or from both combined."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Natural meaning of income per US precedent in dissent.
